moves.1. e4 c5: Sicilian - Statistically the best opening for black
moves.2. d3 Nc6: Watching d4 and preventing a push on e5
moves.3. Be3 e6: Opening up for my bishop to defend c5 and preparing d5
moves.7. Qd2: Nc4 and I win either the bishop or the knight with d4
moves.7... Qxa4 8. Qe2 Be6: continuing development ... maybe i should have gone Nf6 here instead in preparation for castling?
moves.9. b3: My queen is about to do a lot of running...
moves.9... Qb4+ 10. Bd2 Qd4 11. Rb1 Nf6: Finally bringing that knight into play
moves.12. Nf3 Qg4: The great escape continues, but I have spacial and material advantage at this point
moves.13... d4: Trying to push for space but...
moves.15... Be7: Preparing to castle and unpinning my light-squared bishop
moves.16. Rd1 Bd5: Attacking and pinning (apparently it's called "x-ray") the vulnerable f3 knight. I'd been meaning to do this for a while but the bishop wsa pinned
moves.17. Bg2 O-O: Two logical moves - also linking the rooks
moves.18. h3: Trying to puch the queen out but starting to weaken the kingside
moves.20. O-O Bxg2: I have material advantage ... why not make it more important?
moves.22. Rde1 h6: I can't remember why I did this move, can anyone tell? (maybe I was scared of a back-row mate)
moves.24. Qf3 Be5: If we exchange bishops I have the open file
moves.25. Bd2 Nd4: If we exchange queens I check and get the bishop
moves.26. Qxb7: A bad move I think, his queen comes away from the danger zone for one pawn. The rooks are linked so there is no threat
moves.26... Qh5 27. Nh4 Rab8: Getting that queen off the a8-h1 diagonal
moves.29. Nxf3 Qxf3: And my queen is right in there
moves.30. Bf4 Bxf4 31. gxf4 Qxh3: His kingside is now completely open
moves.32. Qxa7: But he does nothing about it
moves.34... Qxf2#: There we go, I think he lost that by lashing out to take b7. Please leave comments, so I can try to improve my game. Valentin
